transcript:
Therapist: You've done a great job today, Hiroshi. I'm impressed by your willingness to practice difficult conversations and to break down the job search into manageable steps. These are important skills that will serve you well as you continue to work on improving your mental health and relationships.

Patient: Thank you, Nova. I feel like I'm making progress, even though it's slow sometimes. It helps to have your support and guidance.

Therapist: I'm glad to hear that, Hiroshi. Remember, progress isn't always linear, and it's okay to have setbacks along the way. The important thing is to keep trying and to be kind to yourself in the process.

Patient: I'll try to remember that. It's hard not to get discouraged sometimes, but I know that I'm doing the best I can.

Therapist: That's right, Hiroshi. You're doing the best you can, and that's all anyone can ask of you. As we continue to work together, we'll keep building on the skills and techniques you're learning and find ways to apply them to your specific challenges and goals.

Patient: I'm looking forward to that. I feel like I'm starting to understand myself better and to see how my thoughts and feelings are connected to my behaviors.

Therapist: That's a great insight, Hiroshi. Understanding those connections is a key part of CBT and can help you make lasting changes in your life. As you continue to practice the techniques we've discussed, you'll likely find that it becomes easier to identify and challenge negative thoughts and to choose behaviors that support your mental health and well-being.

Patient: I hope so. It's still hard sometimes, but I'm willing to keep trying.

Therapist: That's all we can ask of ourselves, Hiroshi. Remember, you don't have to do this alone. You have my support, and you also have the support of your sister and other people who care about you.

Patient: That's true. I'm grateful for the support I have, even if it's hard to ask for help sometimes.

Therapist: Asking for help can be difficult, but it's a sign of strength, not weakness. It takes courage to be vulnerable and to let others in. I'm glad you're able to see the value in reaching out for support when you need it.

Patient: Thank you, Nova. I appreciate you saying that. It means a lot to me to know that I have people in my corner.

Therapist: You absolutely do, Hiroshi. And I'm one of those people. I'm here to support you and to help you work towards your goals, whatever they may be.

Patient: Thank you. That gives me a lot of hope for the future.

Therapist: You have many reasons to be hopeful, Hiroshi. You're doing the hard work of facing your challenges and making changes in your life, and that's something to be proud of. As we continue to work together, I'm confident that you'll see even more progress and growth.
